content.description: A space station has a mass <math alttext="M" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and orbits Earth in a circular orbit at a height above Earth’s surface.
content.question: An astronaut in the space station appears weightless because the astronaut seems to float. Which of the following claims is true about the force exerted on the astronaut by Earth?

choices.label: There is no force exerted on the astronaut by Earth because the astronaut is <math alttext="400 kilometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>km</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> above Earth’s surface.

The force exerted on the astronaut by Earth is less than the force exerted on Earth by the astronaut because the astronaut is <math alttext="400 kilometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>km</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> above Earth’s surface.
The force exerted on the astronaut by Earth is equal to the force exerted on Earth by the astronaut.
The force exerted on the astronaut by Earth is equal to the gravitational force of the space station that is exerted on the astronaut; the two equal forces balance to cause the astronaut to float.

content.answer: The force exerted on the astronaut by Earth is equal to the force exerted on Earth by the astronaut.
